title: 41  Missing Overview
text:
41.2 Imputation
One of the most common ways of dealing with missing values is to fill them in with some values. The types of methods that do this can be split into two groups. Simple imputation in Chapter 42 is when you use the values in the variable to impute its missing values, which is where mean and mode imputation are found. Anything more complicated than this will be found in Chapter 43. This is where multiple columns are used to determine the type of imputation needed.

title: 41  Missing Overview
text:
41.3 Indication
If you suspect that the data is not missing at random, it might be worthwhile to include the missingness as an indicator in your data. We will see how we can do that in Chapter 44.

title: 41  Missing Overview
text:
41.4 Removal
As a last resort, you might want to remove variables or rows with missing data, we will see how that is done in Chapter 45. This chapter is put last in this section, as it is generally not the preferred action, and all other avenues should be considered before removal is done.




RUBIN, DONALD B. 1976. “Inference and missing data.” Biometrika 63 (3): 581–92. https://doi.org/10.1093/biomet/63.3.581.
